events.originalText: Cyclone Numa, a rare "medicane", made landfall in Greece to become the worst weather event that the country had experienced since 1977.
events.subtitle: Cyclone Numa
events.headline: Cyclone Numa hits Greece, worst weather event since 1977

events.originalText: Two Palestinian men attacked the praying congregants of a synagogue in Jerusalem with axes, knives, and a gun, resulting in eight deaths, including the attackers themselves.
events.subtitle: 2014 Jerusalem synagogue attack
events.headline: Eight dead in Jerusalem synagogue attack

events.originalText: With its ruling in Goodridge v. Department of Public Health, the Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court made the state the first in the U.S. to legalize same-sex marriage.
events.subtitle: Goodridge v. Department of Public Health
events.headline: Massachusetts legalizes same-sex marriage

events.originalText: Texas A&M University's Aggie Bonfire collapsed, killing 12 people and injuring 27 others, and causing the university to officially declare a hiatus on the 90-year-old annual event.
events.subtitle: Texas A&M University
events.headline: 12 killed in Texas A&M Aggie Bonfire collapse

events.originalText: The current flag of Uzbekistan was adopted, making the country the first newly independent republic in Central Asia to choose a new flag.
events.subtitle: Flag of Uzbekistan
events.headline: Uzbekistan adopts new flag

events.originalText: Croatian War of Independence: The Yugoslav People's Army captured the Croatian city of Vukovar, ending an 87-day siege.
events.subtitle: Croatian War of Independence
events.headline: Yugoslav People's Army captures Vukovar in Croatian War of Independence

events.originalText: An underground fire killed 31 people at King's Cross St Pancras tube station in London.
events.subtitle: King's Cross fire
events.headline: 31 killed in underground fire at King's Cross St Pancras tube station

events.originalText: Calvin and Hobbes, a comic strip by Bill Watterson that was at its height one of the most popular in the world, was first published.
events.subtitle: Calvin and Hobbes
events.headline: Calvin and Hobbes comic strip first published

events.originalText: Jim Jones led more than 900 members of the Peoples Temple to mass murder/suicide in Jonestown, Guyana, hours after some of its members assassinated U.S. Congressman Leo Ryan.
events.subtitle: Jim Jones
events.headline: Mass murder/suicide in Jonestown, Guyana by Peoples Temple

events.originalText: Solomon Islands ratified the adoption of a new flag (pictured).
events.subtitle: Flag of Solomon Islands
events.headline: Solomon Islands adopts new flag

events.originalText: At the Polish embassy in Moscow, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev said "We will bury you" while addressing Western envoys, prompting them to leave the room.
events.subtitle: Nikita Khrushchev
events.headline: Nikita Khrushchev says 'We will bury you' at Polish embassy in Moscow

events.originalText: American suffragette Susan B. Anthony was arrested and fined $100 for having voted in the presidential election two weeks earlier.
events.subtitle: Suffragette
events.headline: Susan B. Anthony arrested for voting in presidential election

events.originalText: "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County" was published, becoming the first great success of American author Mark Twain (pictured).
events.subtitle: The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County
events.headline: Mark Twain's 'The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County' published

events.originalText: Napoleonic Wars: In the Bay of Bengal, a French frigate squadron captured three East Indiamen mainly carrying recruits for the Indian Army.
events.subtitle: Napoleonic Wars
events.headline: French frigate squadron captures East Indiamen in Bay of Bengal

events.originalText: The Siege of Godes­berg, the first major siege of the Cologne War, began.
events.subtitle: Siege of Godesberg
events.headline: Siege of Godesberg begins in Cologne War

events.originalText: Otto IV, Holy Roman Emperor, was ex­com­mu­ni­cated by Pope Innocent III after Otto commanded him to annul the Concordat of Worms.
events.subtitle: Otto IV, Holy Roman Emperor
events.headline: Holy Roman Emperor Otto IV excommunicated by Pope Innocent III
